name: Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT)
summary: A structured, skills-based psychotherapy that combines cognitive-behavioral strategies with mindfulness to treat emotion dysregulation, self-destructive behaviors, and interpersonal difficulties.
description: Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) is an evidence-based psychotherapy originally developed for borderline personality disorder and chronic suicidality, but now applied to a wide range of conditions involving emotion dysregulation. DBT integrates cognitive-behavioral techniques with mindfulness and dialectical philosophy, emphasizing acceptance and change. It is structured, skills-oriented, and delivered in multiple formats including individual therapy, skills groups, and phone coaching.

contraindications: Severe cognitive impairment preventing skills learning
Lack of safety in high-risk patients without adequate support
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Safe and non-invasive, but intense emotional work may temporarily increase distress.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Very strong—supported by numerous randomized controlled trials and meta-analyses.
clinical_metadata.research_support: DBT has the strongest empirical base for BPD and suicidality, with growing evidence in eating disorders, PTSD, and substance use.

sections.text: DBT combines acceptance strategies (mindfulness, validation) with change-oriented strategies (behavioral skills, problem-solving). The dialectical approach emphasizes balancing acceptance and change. Skills modules include mindfulness, distress tolerance, emotion regulation, and interpersonal effectiveness, which together target emotional instability and maladaptive behaviors.

sections.preparation: Initial assessment, goal setting, and commitment to treatment.
procedure: Weekly individual therapy sessions focusing on behavior analysis and skill application.
Weekly group skills training covering mindfulness, distress tolerance, emotion regulation, and interpersonal effectiveness.
Phone coaching for real-time skills support.
Therapist consultation team meetings to maintain fidelity.
sections.frequency: Typically weekly individual and weekly group sessions.

sections.pre_session: Diary card review of behaviors and skills practice.
sections.treatment_phase: Target behaviors through chain analysis, practice DBT skills.
sections.post_session: Homework assignments and skill application plans.

common: Emotional discomfort during exposure to painful memories
uncommon: Temporary increase in distress when learning new skills
rare: Dropout due to intensity of treatment demands

relative: Low motivation for structured skills training

ideal_candidates: Patients with chronic suicidality or self-injury

practitioner: Licensed therapists trained in DBT through formal certification programs
facility: Mental health clinics, hospitals, private practices, telehealth

studies: Linehan MM et al. (2006). Two-year randomized controlled trial of DBT for borderline personality disorder. Arch Gen Psychiatry.
Kliem S, Kröger C, Kosfelder J. (2010). DBT for borderline personality disorder: A meta-analysis using random effects. J Consult Clin Psychol.
sections.limitations: Resource intensive; requires high patient commitment; dropout rates can be significant.

sections.total_treatment_cost: Can range from $5,000–$15,000 depending on program length
sections.insurance_coverage: Often covered for BPD or high-risk diagnoses
sections.cost_effectiveness: High when considering reductions in hospitalization and crisis service use

lifestyle_recommendations: Consistent use of DBT diary cards

sections.adolescents: DBT-A is adapted for younger populations with strong efficacy evidence.
sections.forensic: DBT used in correctional settings for aggression and impulse control.
sections.substance_use: DBT-S targets patients with co-occurring substance use disorders.

items: DBT emphasizes both acceptance and change, requiring strong commitment from clients.
Therapist consultation team is a key component to prevent burnout and maintain fidelity.
Skills generalization to everyday life is critical for success.
